content: The Act titled "Prohibiting Detention of Youth Status Offenders Act of 2017" aims to deinstitutionalize status offenders. Section 223 of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions regarding the placement of juveniles in secure detention facilities or correctional facilities. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for placing juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders, with specific requirements for issuing a written order detailing the violation and the lack of less restrictive alternatives. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for placing juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders, with specific requirements for issuing a written order detailing the violation and the lack of less restrictive alternatives. The court order must specify the length of time, not exceeding 3 days, for the juvenile to remain in the facility, and include a release plan. The order cannot be renewed or extended, and subsequent orders are prohibited. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for placing juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders. Procedures are in place to ensure juveniles do not remain in custody longer than 3 days or the time authorized by the court or state law. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to limit the secure custody of juveniles to once every six months, with conditions to be met. States must eliminate the use of valid court orders for locking up status offenders within one year of enactment, with a possible one-year extension for hardship. States can apply for extensions for compliance. States may apply for a one-year extension to comply with restrictions on placing status offenders in secure detention facilities. The application must demonstrate progress in reducing such placements and outline a plan to achieve compliance within the extension period.
